entry.title: cauchy schwarz and beyond
entry.content:
exposition

Let’s start from the beginning. We will state some different forms of the cauchy schwarz inequality, prove the form involving dot products and cover what I think is a really cool problem that uses the inequality.

For the different forms of the cauchy schwarz inequality, we have

  • Probability Theory: \(\lvert \mathbb{E}(XY) vert^{2} \leq \mathbb{E}(X^{2}) \mathbb{E}(Y^{2})\).
  • \(\mathbb{R}^2\)-dot product: \(\vert { f a} \cdot { f b} \vert^{2} \leq ({ f a} \cdot { f a}) \; ({ f b} \cdot { f b})\) .
  • \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\): \(n\)-dimensional Euclidean Space: \(\left(\sum \limits_{i = 1}^{n} u_{i} v_{i} ight)^{2} \leq \left(\sum \limits_{i = 1}^{n} u_i ight)^{2} \left(\sum \limits_{i = 1}^{n} v_i ight)^{2}\)

the actual theorem

cauchy schwarz theorem

For all vectors \({ f a}\) and \({ f b}\) in \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\), we have that

$$\vert\ { f a} \cdot { f b} \vert^{2} \leq \vert \vert { f a} \vert \vert^{2} \vert \vert { f b} \vert \vert^{2}$$

a proof based on first principles

proof 1:

Let \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) be vectors living in \(\mathbb{R}^{n}\) such that \(\mathbf{a} = (a_1, a_2, a_3, \dots, a_n)\) and \(\mathbf{b} = (b_1, b_2, b_3, \dots, b_n)\). We first simplify both sides of the inequality, and proceed from there.

We have that,

$$ egin{align*} \lvert\ { f a} \cdot { f b} vert^{2} &= ({ f a} \cdot { f b}) ({ f a} \cdot { f b}) \ &= \langle a_1, a_2, a_3, \dots, a_n angle \langle b_1, b_2, b_3, \dots, b_n angle \ &= (a_1 b_1 + a_2 b_2 + \dots + a_n b_n) (a_1 b_1 + a_2 b_2 + \dots + a_n b_n) \ &= (a_1 b_1 + a_2 b_2 + \dots + a_n b_n)^{2} \ &= \left(\sum_{i = 1}^{n} a_i b_i ight)^2 = D^2 \ ({ f a} \cdot { f a}) &= \langle a_1, a_2, a_3, \dots, a_n angle \langle a_1, a_2, a_3, \dots, a_n angle \ &= a_{1}^{2} + a_{2}^{2} + \dots a_{n}^{2} \ &= \sum_{i = 1}^{n} a_{i}^{2} = A \ ({ f b} \cdot { f b}) &= \langle b_1, b_2, b_3, \dots, b_n angle \langle b_1, b_2, b_3, \dots, b_n angle \ ({ f b} \cdot { f b}) &= b_{1}^{2} + b_{2}^{2} + \dots + b_{n}^{2} \ &= \sum_{i = 1}^{n} b_{i}^{2} = B \end{align*} $$

So we are therefore tasked with proving the following inequality, \(D^{2} \leq AB\). Rearranging provides

$$ egin{align*} &\ D^{2} \leq AB \ &\ D^{2} - AB \leq 0 \ &\ 4D^{2} - 4AB \leq 0 && ext{Multiplying both sides by 4} \ &\ (2D)^{2} - 4AB \leq 0 \end{align*} $$

This might look familiar to some people already but given a quadratic equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\), the discrimanant \(D_{Q}\) is given by \(b^{2} - 4ac\).

Given this observation, we can prove an equivalent statement to the inequality we wish to show, namely that the quadratic equation given by \(Ax^2 + 2Dx + B\) has no real roots or exactly one real root. This is because the discrimanant of this quadratic equation is given by \(4D^{2} - 4AB\), and the same would imply that \(4D^{2} - 4AB \leq 0\), which is exactly what we want :)

Substituting in the values for \(A\), \(B\), and \(D\), we have that

$$ egin{align*} Ax^2 + 2Dx + B &= \left(a_1^2 + \dots + a_n^2 ight) x^2 + 2 \left(a_1 b_1 + \dots + a_n b_n ight) x + \left(b_1^2 + \dots + b_n^2 ight) \ &= \left(a_1^2 x^2 + \dots + a_n x^2 ight) + 2 \left(a_1 b_1 x + \dots + a_n b_n x ight) + \left(b_1^2 x^2 + \dots + b_n^2 x^2 ight) \ &= \left(a_1^2 x^2 + 2a_1 b_1 x + b_1^2 ight) + \dots + \left(a_n^2 x^2 + 2a_n b_n x + b_n^2 ight) \ &= \left(a_1 x + b_1 ight)^2 + \dots + \left(a_n x + b_n ight)^2 \ &\geq 0 \end{align*} $$

  • case 1: \(Ax^2 + 2Dx + B > 0\) In this case, we have that the quadratic equation has no real roots, which is exactly one of the conditions we want.
  • case 2: \(Ax^2 + 2Dx + B = 0\) Note that this is equivalent to saying that \(\left(a_1 x + b_1 ight)^2 + \dots + \left(a_n x + b_n ight)^2 = 0\) which necessarily implies that for all \(i \in \{1, 2, \dots, n\}\), \(a_i x + b_i = 0\), which implies that the equation only has one real root, thereby satisfying the second condition we want and completing the proof.

calculus is nice, i guess

proof 2: This is a proof that at least to me feels slightly more natural, and personally I think this proof technique is cooler (I may be biased here though).

We begin by defining the function \(f(t) = \|\mathbf{x} - t\mathbf{y}\|^2 = \langle \mathbf{x} - t\mathbf{y}, \mathbf{x} - t\mathbf{y} angle\). Simplifying, this gives us

$$ egin{align*} f(t) &= \langle \mathbf{x} - ty, \mathbf{x} - t\mathbf{y} angle \ &= \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x} - t\mathbf{y} angle - t \langle y, \mathbf{y} - t\mathbf{y} angle \ &= \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x} angle - t\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle - t \left(\langle \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{x} angle - t \langle \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y} angle ight) \ &= \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x} angle - 2t \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle + t^2 \langle \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y} angle \ &= \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 - 2t \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle + t^2 \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 \end{align*} $$

Since \(f(t) = \|\mathbf{x} - t\mathbf{y}\|^2\), we have that \(f(t) \geq 0\) for all \(t \in \mathbb{R}\). We make the clever observation of exploiting this fact for the minima of \(f\), and proceed to find the derivative, set it equal to 0, and solve for \(t_{ ext{min}}\).

$$ egin{align*} f'(t) &= -2 \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle + 2t \|\mathbf{y}\|^2\ 0 &= -2 \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle + 2t_{ ext{min}} \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 && ext{Setting $$f'(t) = 0$$} \ -2 \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle &= 2t_{ ext{min}} \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 \ \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle &= t_{ ext{min}} \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 && ext{Dividing both sides by 2} \ t_{ ext{min}} &= rac{\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle}{\|\mathbf{y}\|^2} && ext{Dividing both sides by $$|\mathbf{y}|^2$$} \end{align*} $$

Evaluating, we have that

$$ egin{align*} f(t_{ ext{min}}) &= \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 - 2t_{ ext{min}} \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle + t_{ ext{min}}^2 \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 \ &= \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 - 2 rac{\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle}{\|\mathbf{y}\|^2} \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle + \left( rac{\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle}{\|\mathbf{y}\|^2} ight)^2 \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 \ &= \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 - 2 rac{\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle}{\|\mathbf{y}\|^2} \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle + \left( rac{\langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle^2}{\|\mathbf{y}\|^2} ight) \ &= rac{\|\mathbf{x}\|^2 \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 - 2 \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle^2 + \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle^2}{\|\mathbf{y}\|^2} \ &= rac{\|\mathbf{x}\|^2 \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 - \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle^2}{\|\mathbf{y}\|^2} \geq 0 \ &\implies \|\mathbf{x}\|^2 \|\mathbf{y}\|^2 - \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle^2 \geq 0 \ &\implies \langle \mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y} angle \leq \|\mathbf{x}\| \|\mathbf{y}\| \end{align*} $$

the promised probabilistic result

fun lemma :D

For a non-negative random variable \(Y\), we have that

$$ rac{\mathbb{E}[Y]^2}{\mathbb{E}[Y^2]} \leq \Pr(Y eq 0) \leq \mathbb{E}[Y]$$

proof: We first prove the right-hand side of the inequality, i.e. \(\Pr(Y eq 0) \leq \mathbb{E}[Y]\). Using the definition of expectation, we have that

$$ egin{align*} \mathbb{E}[Y] &= \sum_{y \in \Omega_{y}} y \cdot \Pr(Y = y) \ &= \sum_{\substack{y \in \Omega_{y} \ y eq 0}} y \cdot \Pr(Y = y) \geq \sum_{y \in \Omega_{y}, y eq 0} \Pr(Y = y) \geq \Pr(Y eq 0) \end{align*} $$

We now prove the left-hand side of the inequality, Consider the expression \(\mathbb{E}[Y^2] \Pr(Y eq 0)\). We have that the following is true

$$ egin{align*} \mathbb{E}[Y]^2 \Pr(Y eq 0) &= \sum_{y eq 0} \underbrace{\Pr(Y = y)}_{a_i = \sqrt{\Pr(Y = y)}} \; \sum_{y eq 0} \underbrace{y^{2} \Pr(Y = y)}_{b_i = y \sqrt{\Pr(Y = y)}} \ &\geq \left(\sum_{y eq 0} y \sqrt{\Pr(Y = y)} \sqrt{\Pr(Y = y)} ight)^2 && ext{Via Cauchy Schwarz} \ &\geq \left(\sum_{y eq 0} y \Pr(Y = y) ight)^2 = \mathbb{E}[Y]^2 \end{align*} $$ which implies the result.
